cons: Working alone or with 1 other can be a lot of pressure for entry level hires. pros: I've had the pleasure of working at CubeSmart for the past ten years, and it has truly been an exceptional experience. Here's why I rate CubeSmart with five stars: 1. Positive Work Environment: CubeSmart stands out for its vibrant and positive work culture. The team is more than just colleagues; it's a supportive group of inclusive and positive collaborators that create an uplifting atmosphere, making every day a joy to be at work. 2. Stability of Industry & Company: The self-storage industry is known for its financial stability, and CubeSmart, as a leading player in the field, reflects this stability. The industry's resilience, even in challenging times, adds a layer of confidence and security to the overall work environment. 3. Career Development Opportunities: CubeSmart excels in recognizing an individual’s worth and areas of strength to their team and the greater organization. Witnessing numerous colleagues being promoted internally highlights the company's commitment to recognizing and nurturing talent, contributing to the positive atmosphere.
cons: As a large publicly held company, things don’t always move as fast as you might like them to. We are a collaborative company that is methodical, thoughtful, and intentional with the decisions we make and the resources that we deploy, always balancing the three elements of what’s best for our customers, what’s best for our teammates, and what’s best for our investors. These approaches are not always easy for a more assertive personality, but it benefits all in the long term.

You are only working with 1 other person in the office so if they are not a team player when it comes to store coverage and switching off days , you can be become miserable very quick.
cons: The pay would be the only downside. They claim to have a lot of growth within the company which is true but the catch is YOU DO NOT GET PAID for that "extra" responsibility . All you get is a title change and a shiny new name badge. I really wish they could focus on teammates who've been with the company for 5 + years rather then hiring newbies at the same rate as long time teammates.

title: Unless its your starting job , don't.
pros: Being able to just make calls and payments all day, sometimes nothing at all depending on the location. Being able to make the move easier or less stressful for the customer as it already is. Uniform ( Tops ) were nice.
cons: The Pay is horrible , might as well take that job title off and put " Sales Associate". For the title at least have it with the deserved pay especially for what the employees have to put up with. Doing it yourself and not hiring a company is the way they save money and make the Store manager or even General Manager do all the disgusting dirty work that may even get us sick. Human Resource department is a failure

title: Tired Of Being Verbally Abused

Verbal abuse to the extent that employees are so stressed that it affects their health, home life and desire to even go to work is beyond shameful. Some extremely talented individuals have been either terminated or driven to resigning for unsubstantiated reasons. Seems like Management can "trump up" instances/reasons for termination or documenting instances based on taking things "out of context". running. If Cubesmart feels this is an example of "Upper Management" everyone (employees and customers) should get out before it too late. If you have Cubesmart stock (CUBE), SELL before you loose your savings.

title: Recently joined the CubeSmart team and am very happy with my decision
pros: I have been very impressed with the leadership; they seem to genuinely care about the teammates and are striving to make positive changes to the company culture and work environment. The people I have met so far are all engaged, energetic, intelligent professionals who I feel I will learn a lot from. The atmosphere at the corporate headquarters is fun and lively. Work-life balance is also high. From my vantage point, compensation seems to be above average. We are making strides towards becoming a true pay-for-performance culture.
cons: The biggest con for me is the limited paid vacation time. I have spoken to several colleagues who feel the same way. I think to be competitive in the marketplace and thought of as an employer of choice, CubeSmart should offer more vacation time. I am also a strong believer that people are more effective and engaged employees when they are encouraged to take more time away.

title: General Manager/ FTS
pros: Always opportunity for growth we are a growing company. Our number one goal is to provide the best Customer service and with that it makes the job that much better! Storage isn't always a good experience or for a good cause most people are stressed out and for us to be able to help in any way even by taking them from that bad experience and giving them the ultimate good Customer service is awesome! Benefits are awesome provide 401k. The pay is good. Training is great. Communication throughout the company is great also. Any changes in policies, benefits anything you name it and we receive a memo emailed to us. Friday's are weekly communications. Upper management is open for suggestions we have something called the idea center and I can say I've submitted ideas which have been taken and put in to play. If I continue I would write a book about CubeSmart and how awesome it is to work for this company! Come to work do what you have to do follow company policies be honest and loyal and you will be great!
cons: Don't know couldn't think of anything CubeSmart is a great company and I'm glad to call myself a CubeSmart teammate.

title: Underpaid and Full Responsibilty
pros: -Work by yourself; nobody breathing down your neck every day. -Your own Boss in a way. - Could be Worse
cons: Working by yourself. Constantly waiting for approval. Empty Promises about Pay and Time off. NO responsibility for upper management or ownership. NO BONUS OR INCENTIVES AT ALL. ADVANCEMENT IS LITTLE; UNLESS YOUR WILLING TO RELOCATE TO 500 MILES AWAY FROM HOME.

title: Storagek
pros: Great customers and being able to help
cons: No weekends and micro managed

title: Excellent Company to work for!
pros: This company cares about its employees. The district managers go above and beyond to make sure we have everything we need to do our jobs safely. When asked how good the company is, the best way to describe it I have is this: I was recently told I was receiving a $250 bonus for my hard work. I thought that's great! I figured, after the higher taxes on bonus I might see $150, but that's still a nice bonus for doing what I see as my job. In reality, the company gave me a $407 bonus, so that after taxes I received the full $250. They didn't have to do that, I wasn't expecting anything like that, but they did it anyway. A company that doesn't care about it's employees wouldn't have bonuses in the first place, let alone anything like this! I'm a proud Cubesmart teammate with over two years in the company, and I've never been happier with my choice of employer.
cons: The annual pay raises are rather low, but given the economy, any raise is a good raise. The medical and dental benefits available aren't comprehensive enough. They cover some, but in truth nowhere near enough.

title: Juggling 90 plates a day for awful pay!
pros: Very few. Vicinity to my house and I like how laid back my fellow GM is. I can bring my laptop to work and just code and work on side hustles on the clock without a care in the world. That's about it. If you have a miserable, power hungry GM who will stab your in the back for a can of Diet Coke and some Spotlight approval from the District Manager, you are screwed, however!
cons: You are a site manager, janitor, accountant (You're expected to make daily bank runs before noon, lol) customer service agent and bill collector all in one! And that's all on a good day! Also, the daily nitpicking of irrelevant, low ROI tasks is appalling. We have glaring cracks on our windows and floors, not to mention 3-4 days a week at a time @ our specific facility the elevator goes out, but our district manager is putting me on the naughty list for wearing sweats on a cold winter day? Way to prioritize the business! Our customer's would rather I wear nothing but a CubeSmart branded thong provided we actually cater to their needs as a company and help them out.

title: Worse place to work

This is the PTO that you work for everyday. Good luck finding people to cover for you. Upper Management - 1st They do not give a DAMN about YOU. Only the numbers you produce . They will try their hardest to paint a different image. I mean lie straight through their teeth for the sake of trying to be someone you know they aren't. Insurance - Cubesmart does offer you insurance but they (Cigna )don't cover much of anything. Raise Structure- $.25 cents raise to maybe $.50 cents . Regardless of hired position you will not receive a raise higher than that. From top to bottom this place needs change. I would honestly recommend Wendy's before you come here and waste your time

title: It’s a job. meh.

title: poor working conditions

pros: *The following is subjective* ~Roth 401(k) contribution ~Tuition Reimbursement (Up to $2,500 /calendar yr) ~Scholarship Opportunities ~Empowerment ~Tremendous Growth Opportunity ~Helpful Team Environment ~Work/Life Balance

title: Happy at the Corporate Office
pros: This company does a lot of positive things – provides good resources and benefits for employees, does charitable work, supports personal growth, and recognizes employee accomplishments. Fun events happen regularly, and new ideas are given a fair shot. Everyone is enjoyable to work with. The company culture is taken fairly seriously, with "fit" playing a large part in evaluating potential hires, and it shows. There is very little of the typical corporate politicking and backbiting that seems to be prevalent in other similar structures.
cons: Sometimes decisions are made without fully vetting all the potential effects. Cross-departmental (and even inter-departmental) communication can get muddled and lost. Resources become thin and strained at times when initiatives are understaffed. There is sometimes a lowkey vibe of "us vs them" when discussing "lower ranks" such as store managers and sales center employees. A few other reviews bring up problems with blatant sexism or racism within the upper echelons; I have never seen anything of the sort. It can be safely said, though, that the headquarters could stand more diversity among the staff, and that there are not many women in higher positions.

title: Careful working here...
pros: Like most jobs, colleagues are probably the best part of the job. Sometimes customers can be really good too. I worked here for close to 4 years, a few years ago the job was better but those times are gone.
cons: How long do you have? My biggest gripe is that they are wage thieves. These clowns did not pay out my Vacation time when they decided to let me go. HR here is bad, unethical, and incompetent. Pay has always been low but this year you will need a second job with this one if you are a sole income. Upper management created a pressure cooker this year and drove off the previous talent who built this company's reputation. Just so you know, goals will shift, management will gaslight you, and you will be doing two employee's work by yourself.

title: I hated every minute working here
pros: Some free food at the office. Facility is nice but God forbid you forget to wipe down the conference tables or turn off the power after you use a conference room. You will be reprimanded and made to feel horrible about yourself. Senior leaders also discourage employees from using the elevators. Had a VP try to tell me I should use the stairs more - and I'm disabled.
cons: I was fed a line of BS to get me in the door: "family" environment, wonderful culture, grow opportunities, culture I have etc. However, it turned out to be the worst culture I've ever seen. A bunch of old white guys running the company with your token HR female leader. Very much a "good old boys" club there - and those who succeed smile and go along with what the good old boys say. Store employees are overworked for a measly hourly wage. Corp HQ is like a cult, where everyone looks the same with the exception of a few, and walk around with fake smiles but they are miserable and terrified of getting the ax at any moment. Lots of back-stabbing and gossiping about coworkers as well.

title: The Truth ( from someone who has < a year, but actually listened to multiple people in your stores!)
pros: Hours, may be good for a retiree or someone looking for a short term job. The company is growing.
cons: Pay, 1% raises ( sometimes less), lots of drama in the stores, management afraid of the next tier of management, GMs who want to control what managers do and who they talk to in the upward chain of command. 2 yearly meetings which are mandatory, just to spit out info readily available to us in the stores. It goes on and on. Upper Management does not listen, even if they believe they do.

title: CubeSmart has been a great company to work for all corporate level bs aside..
pros: - Competitive Pay - Bonus Potential - Nice Workflow Mix - Annual Raises - Relatively Easy Work - Close at 6PM (No Nights)
cons: - Only two people per store and you’re by yourself two days a week (gets lonely, boring) - Schedule changes with so little staff is very challenging - Corporate has 3-5 more holidays per year then store level teammates which seems highly unfair to us ground level folk - Store Managers are required to work Saturdays and Sundays which really lowers morale and is inconsiderate of our personal lives (time with friends, family, etc) - Weekly district conference calls are highly repetitive

title: Good Luck

Be ready to have irate customers that bombard you daily. Gms/mgrs are what provide this company with the money to build it. Yet we are at the BOTTOM of the food chain in this company with little to no recoginition. Only critiques. One of the many reason I'm leaving.

My previous company scored in the 30-40%'s. I honestly look forward to coming to work every day.
cons: I haven't been here too long yet, so I haven't noticed anything really bad. I have no problem making an update in the future if there's something I feel is worthy to share.

title: Not the best, but no way near the worst......good starter/ out of college job

cons: -You have to "blend in"...especially if you want to go higher up in the company. -a little personality is good. a lot makes you a "target". -everyone is an adult, but if HR gets involved,my experience has been that the person who complains 1st, wins. Right or Wrong is irrelevant .

title: Overall great career
pros: Working at CubeSmart is a great career. You are always learning things no matter what your title is. A typical day is some office work, on the computer. Checking the property for move outs and cleanliness. Taking care of new Customers that walk in and rent and also the ones that move in online contactless. The culture is very welcoming; any teammate company wide is willing to help you as needed. The district manager, divisional vice president, and corporate are always helpful and friendly. I'd say the hardest part of the job is cleaning cubes outside when it gets above 90 degrees but you do have time for breaks as needed. The most enjoyable part of working here is being on your own basically, you are running a store and property with one other person usually, sometimes 2, and as long as you do what needs done you are trusted to keep the store running. It's a lot of responsibility but overall it does help you grow as a person.
cons: Working out in the heat

title: General Manager
pros: The CEO lets you know what he is thinking through online video's that they do each week. They have a "facebook" also known as "instawow" where you can get to know your employers and what they look like. The culture they really allow you to assist the customers and they leave it to you. you have some freedom
cons: Not enough compensation for the work that you do. They aren't exactly welcome only because when you are first hired on you work 1 location so you really don't get to know your coworkers. and the balance between work and regular life is terrible. If you have a day off they kind of expect you to stay around just incase something happens. (they wont say that to you but they do) If you have a coworker who is suppose to show up but doesn't then you have to come in because its usually a "general manager" a "manager" and if your lucky you have a second "manager"

title: Great Culture
pros: I started with CubeSmart just under two years ago and all I can say is WOW! I had no previous self-storage experience, but I was still welcomed into the family with open arms. The support you receive from all levels is insurmountable. It wasn’t long after joining CubeSmart that I realized the culture was exceptional, and the longer I have been exposed to the working world, the more I realize that a supportive culture can be elusive to find. The executive team guides with strong principals that promote ethics, our values and mission. It’s also rewarding when you have the freedom to reach out to anyone from upper management, knowing that they are open to ideas and committed to doing the right thing for their employees and Customers. I would certainly recommend working for CubeSmart to any employee; it’s been a great ride so far!
cons: None at this present time.

title: A Great Place to Work
pros: CubeSmart has AWESOME people who work there and are dedicated to creating a WOW! experience for their Customers and each other! The WOW! culture has grown tremendously over the last few years and the CEO Chris Marr is on a quest to make the company more innovative, collaborative, and positive for all teammates. The reward programs are good and the family atmosphere makes going to work a great experience. The growth of the company is opening up a lot of doors for many teammates across the company.
cons: It would be better if we had a PTO policy instead of vacation/sick time. Also, offering more days off would be beneficial and would stay competitive with other companies.

title: Great job, as long as it comes with living accommodations
pros: The 'free' apartment is by far, one of the best perks you could get in a job of this level. The benefits package offered is also highly competitive for a job at this pay scale.
cons: If you do not get an apartment as a General Manager, the company will try to tell you that a 1-2 dollar per hour raise ($172-$344 per month) is equal to a free apartment with free utilities, which in the market I worked in, worth 1200-1500 per month.

title: Get Out While You Can!
pros: There really isn't any pros about working here, I guess the only pro would be you never really see your boss, so you have little supervision.

Working here you really have to watch your back and just worry about yourself.

Micro management from the Divisional Vice President is non stop for issues that don't really effect daily operations of the location.

title: Work somewhere else...

We're even willing to meet half way and work half in the AM then have off. But no they can care less on the happiness of their employees. Benefits suck. Find a better place to work.

title: Get it Right!

title: An Excellent Opportunity for Personal & Professional Growth
pros: • Pay is among the highest in the self-storage industry with annual increases. • PTO and Health Benefits are among best offered anywhere • Complete and clear onboard training programs and excellent progressive training programs available • Expectations are clearly described in policy and procedure • Great Employee Recognition Programs in place for achievers • Success or failure is entirely self-formed
cons: • Compared to how well CubeSmart performs in the national market, annual increases in the field are extremely nominal. • Bonuses & incentives in the field (where the selling & service occurs) are a pint-sized end result of a trickle down through a very large funnel. • Field employees are asked to participate in Surveys and Leader Assessments, but never hear results or see changes where they are needed.

title: District Manager in Training
pros: Great Pay, Great Training Program put in place. Good chances to learn from upper management. Got to travel a lot and meet different people in the company. Met some really great people during my time working here.

Every job has it cons you either can deal with it or you can't. Very simple, some people have a great experience some where or a bad one. Work is work.

title: ok..

title: Stress-Filled and Abusive Working Environment
pros: The pay is decent... and not much else. There's a gym on the premises to work off stress, which is a godsend.

All the stops are pulled out to make that month's budget and revenue goals, only to have to stress about the following month all over again because there was no strategy involved. Management can be abusive and cronyism is rampant. I witnessed inappropriate advances toward female subordinates. The previous CEO was very demanding but rewarded those who met his expectations. CubeSmart's current CEO is a blank slate who avoids talking to junior associates and in an internal meeting could not understand why the office should be closed for inclement weather.

title: General Manager
pros: Decent hours with nice apartment. The responsibilities are varied & you don't have to be trapped in the office all the time. I enjoyed most of my tenants & it was a pleasure serving them.
cons: Top down company with upper management having little to no experience actually running a storage facility. No advancement past GM position. Tend to over react to one bad manager and assume everyone is doing the same things

title: Store Manager at CubeSmart
pros: Really nice and good people for the most part as far as employees go. Most of the customers that you come into contact with are awesome. Real people just like me and you. The general work is probably the easiest there is anywhere.
cons: Upper management on up are text book examples of Micro Managers. They have a Mission Statement and a set of Values that they do not adhere to. All the decisions made by upper management are filtered down to the store level and the employees working the store are expected to defend and enforce them on their own. Upper management will not address customers directly unless they threaten legal action or some kind of social media retaliation..

pros: I can't say very much that is good about CubeSmart because they use people and then when that tries to fight back they get let go or reprimanded for something they should be reprimanded for in the first place. Also we are over worked and underpaid and people that should be fired get away with everything and the one who deserve to be praised aren't.
cons: I believe that the one big con work for CubeSmart would be that they way over people and never pay them what they are worth and then they use people until they go crazy and find a way to fire so they don't have to worry about the consequences.

title: Accountant

title: Great Company

They have also demonstrated the desire and ability to promote from within throughout all ranks in the company. Their new District Manager in Training program has already produced a new District Manager with more undoubtedly to come. CubeSmart has provided my family excellent opportunities. I'm proud to call myself a CubeSmart teammate!
cons: I love CubeSmart and don't have anything negative to say.

title: Don't do it, this company does not care about you at all
pros: It's was a pay check

title: Do not take the job if you are offered to work at a 3pm store
pros: It's a job, OK pay and OK benefits
cons: 3pm stores are not owned by cubesmart, just run by cs, store owner could decide to sell at a whim and you could be jobless just that quick, starting to push secret shops again, workers in the stores already have so much to deal with, (short staffed, increasingly difficult customers, never getting anything approved to get fixed, and so on) the last thing stores need is the added stress and harassment due to worrying about being shopped.

title: It's mostly a good place
pros: There is a certain amount of autonomy in the stores, so it's an ideal job for self motivated individuals. You can make a difference by simply caring about the property and your customers and being willing to commit to giving 100% when working. It's interesting and varied, no two days are the same. There is a good blend of office and outside work, so it doesn't get boring. The customers are an interesting mix and it's nice to be able to improve someone's day with such a simple service. For the most part, the coworkers are helpful and caring, and fun to work with. Paid vacation, sick time. Company match 401K. Some properties have onsite apartments. Uniform is comfortable, 5 shirts provided annually. The "free" apartment is by far the best perk of this job, although it is really earned with after hours work and dealing with customers at your door after business hours.
cons: Inconsistency, lack of communication, and low pay/ only so-so benefits for amount of work required The district managers are not all on the same page, even though this supposedly has been addressed. Changes are made and not communicated, and everyone is just supposed to know. Not all employees are treated the same. Some people can be chronically late, spend the day chatting on cell phones, or doing their nails and are paid more(!) than someone who is dedicated, punctual, and spends the day cleaning, renting, fielding complaints, and making collection calls. Some employees can be constantly rude to customers and coworkers alike, even calling people offensive names, with no fear of reprisal. Complaints about this do little good (except to be called a negative person), as this company seems afraid to address personnel issues in a timely manner. There is constant mention of how well the company is doing, and how profitable each year is, but the field workers see very little of this money. Maintenance on properties takes begging and pleading and employees who already have enough to do are required to clean gutters, fill potholes,repair golf carts, change light fixtures, plumbing, and other things that should be hired out , bonuses are practically nonexistent, and pay raises are microscopic. The extreme rate increases in the past two years have caused major complaints from long term customers, as they don't see any of the money going back into properties. CubeSmart's culture seems to be to complicate the simplest things for maximum frustration and irritation. In 30 years of corporate culture/customer service, I have never before seen a company so dedicated to making one step into three steps.

title: It's alright
pros: - Self-storage is not too crazy of an industry, so the work-life balance is good. Not great. - Most other pros have evaporated since the pandemic.
cons: - Management is largely incompetent, depending on the situation this is a pro but usually it is a con. - Salary is not competitive. - Remote work policy was laughable . . . Thanks you Comrade Corona :o)

title: General Manager/FTS
pros: cubesmart is a great place to work I Enjoy training new employees, I like having weekly meeting with my team. I create an end of month report and share all the numbers with my team in order for us to continue improving our number's
cons: i feel the company dont give recognition to the Gm's and their team for turning the number's around,example is when I took over the current store i'm in the number were not in a good area, a/r were over 12% rentals were below budget square feet was low in one year the a/r dropped to 2% rentals are always above budget square foot was 47% currently is at 73%

title: General Manager
pros: I enjoy the sense of community in the company and the options to get help when needed. The benefits are great and they really push for moving up in the company. Its okay to seek help and advice when needed and they are working hard to create a really good work environment. They're always taking employee suggestions on how to improve what the individual stores have to do so they're really catering to as many people as they can.
cons: There's usually only 2 people per store so moving around schedules can be a little difficult but there are so many people in the district you can look for help so it usually doesn't become a problem.

title: Going Downhill Fast!
pros: There is a degree of freedom, as you will work alone quite a bit, which is nice. If you are running a successful store, your district manager will trust you to make most of the decisions regarding your store, provided they don't cost too much money. Customers are great! I love my customers!
cons: There are so many downsides to this company right now. I am absolutely sure that they do not care about the people on the ground at all. We are scolded for minor cosmetic issues on the rare occasion that someone from corporate shows up. There is no recognition for the money we bring in or good work we do. We have a bonus structure created solely to keep us from making 'too much' money. My store bonus has gone from around 300 a month to around 100, or less, despite the fact that we increase occupancy in our store nearly monthly, and that's a situation that's not going to change anytime soon due to the overinflated monthly budget goal we are required to reach to get the bare minimum. The maintenance!! It's a huge con. A maintenance staff member hired to float between properties would be an easy fix to this, but I don't see that happening. I'll add one more con for anyone in corporate that may be reading this..rate increases this year were much too high. We have to justify these 10, 20, and 30 per cube increases to our customers, many of whom have 2 or 3 cubes, and telling them that we have to 'look out for our shareholders', as suggested, just doesn't cut it.

title: Senior Manager
pros: This company is growing so fast, there is many opportunities to grow your career. They provide full time positions with great benefits. They give u a chance to make decisions that best fit the business and not be micromanaged every step of the way. Upper management is also very easy to talk to and understanding. They always have their employees best interest in mind. I have promoted 3 times in the last 6 years
cons: Raises can be better but they are pretty competitive with other companies and give raises yearly

title: Stop making things harder then needed
pros: no nights, fair pay, good benefits
cons: expectations high and not scheduling to help meet them, not getting things repaired correctly, older properties left to rot for the sake of newer properties, tie or hands to get stuff done then attack us for not getting it done.

title: Manager
pros: -Easy work -Frequent "down time" -Day to day activities vary enough to avoid monotony -Minor sales experience without being on commission -Stress free -Monthly bonus based on store revenue and sales
cons: - Workplace environment is greatly dependant on management. If your store or district manager is unreasonable or likes to micromanage, the job is uncomfortable. - Compensation is poor and raises are extremely small (~1%) - Company leadership is extremely segregated from retail stores often leading to strange and unrealistic policy. -Generally days off are not flexible. - Benefits are offered but unreasonably expensive. - Company is extremely unwilling to spend money on necessary goods such as merchandise or cleaning supplies.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: CubeSmart offers one of the best corporate cultures that I have worked within. The leadership team cares about what is best for the teammates. People are very welcoming, supportive and collaborative. Business leaders listen to suggestions and offerings with an open mind and have a keen focus on innovation and ways to improve the overall business operation. The company has a wonderful rewards and recognition platform that is widely used and everyone is very supportive of one another.
cons: Systems and technology is a bit outdated and some systems do not support the growth of the company.

title: Genuine company that cares about the right things.
pros: CubeSmart has a unique culture where every teammate really does have the opportunity to make a difference and to develop themselves. What's even more special is how much of a team feel you get at CubeSmart. The people are warm and welcoming. There's very little politicking. People have the right intentions and work hard to do the right things for each other and for our customers. Management listens to opinions and treats teammates like they matter and their opinions matter.
cons: Overall, it's the best place I've ever worked. If one thing could improve, it would be flexibility for work arrangements. While some flexibility exists, there is still some stigma around working remotely or flexible hours.

title: Enjoyed myself
pros: What I enjoyed is that I worked alone most day & the pay , and at the time of employment we as gM had set off days & we would only work most days 9:30-6P (business hours)
cons: If you and your store manager or other team mate don’t get along you are suck together every day you work until on of your are off work/ sometimes you have to cover other store a little far out / you have to upkeep your property and kill your own bugs like spider, wasp, etc so save them money on pest control .

title: Nice people but not a well-run company, and low pay
pros: Everyone I worked with at CubeSmart was very nice, intelligent and hard working. Even the senior leadership were nice and approachable. The culture pre-Covid was unique and fun, almost like a tech start-up kind of feel...without the 70 hour work weeks, though it definitely has suffered post-pandemic. Health and retirement benefits are about average with a decent but antiquated PTO policy, though that's been improved over the years through more attention and empowerment of Human Resources. Advancement from within is possible, though with some caveats. The self-storage industry is resilient and seems to do well regardless of macroeconomic factors, and CubeSmart benefiits from this. The senior leaders run the company well from a financial management perspective. Diversity and inclusion are good and have improved dramatically over the years. It's overall a good place to work, especially to start a career, but not without some really ugly warts.
cons: The company grew very rapidly over the last 10 years, and the senior leaders are a mainly the same people that ran it 10 years ago. That continuity is nice but I'm not sure those leaders, and the many second level leaders who were promoted, are all capable of handling of running a much larger company. They still micromanage everything like they did when the company was small. There's very little high level strategic leadership. Their success has led to a certain level of arrogance, making them blind or indifferent to problems certain problems. They could definitely benefit from some new blood from outside the industry in senior leadership. The systems needed to keep pace are insufficient because they try to do everything in house without enough money, people or resources needed to support that. Pay below the executive level is uncompetitive, leading to being short staffed across the company, from the stores, to the call center, to IT, and most other departments to some degree as well. This had led to burnout among good people who are working hard for substandard pay, so they're leaving in droves. Meanwhile the senior execs are paid extraordinarily well and seem either unwilling to admit fault, or just don't see it. Not sure which it is, nor which is worse. Dissent is not tolerated. There's some politics like anywhere, but favorites definitely tend to get promoted beyond their capabilities. All this has led to a feeling that leadership either just doesn't know what they're doing, or maybe they do but they just don't care despite their lip-service to culture and genuine care. In the end, we all know it's about dollars, but leadership and longterm success are enhanced by doing more than just capably managing the finances quarter to quarter.

title: Cubesmart does not promote from within outside of the home office.
pros: Unfortunately there are not many for those that work in the stores. The only one I can think of is that we don't have to work a night shift.
cons: Cubesmart does not back up it's claim that they promote from within for those people working in the field. If you want to advance beyond the position of General Manager this is not the place to work.

title: It is what you make it
pros: I am going to try not to be biased because I am a trainer for this company, but there are a lot of great reasons to work for CubeSmart. This company is customer service. The company reputation and rapid growth are the main results for great customer service. You get to meet lots of new people, build long lasting relationships with co workers and customers, you get the benefit of working in an office and outside on property, because of the rapid growth the opportunity to climb the ladder is there, and there is always ways to make extra money based on your performance. You will be a sales person. The goal is to sell storage like you are selling a house. A real esate agent doesn't get the big money unless they get the sale...its the same concept at CubeSmart.
cons: Working in property management, it is what you make it. Some people take advantage of the independence we get as managers and do not take ownership of their properties. This job is NOT hard, at all! You just have to be on top of your work, get it done and then you might have down time depending on how your store pace. It is an on call 24/7 job, however the better you take care of your property and customers, you shouldn't be getting too many calls after hours. There are always issues with abandoned furniture that we are responsible for getting rid of, but big projects like that you should never have to do alone. I think one thing to consider while reading these reviews is that people are lazy. Most people my age (20-30) just don't know the meaning of "hard work". Most who apply at CubeSmart think that it is just an office job. IT IS NOT. BUT all aspects of the job are pretty easy.

Everything was done in a timely manner. The District manager i worked under cared about the employees and helped immediately when needed. This company also offers opportunities to hard workers. There are also monthly bonuses based on occupancy and how many customers you rent.

pros: Compensation for corporate jobs is very competitive. The new corporate headquarters is beautiful and contains a gym, large outside patio and other luxuries. The newest HR regime has made an effort to improve training.
cons: The atmosphere is strained at all times and gossip is out of control. After the recent CEO transition, power is centralized among several executives who take every opportunity to shift blame to others. The company has experienced two years of excellent growth but did not share success with non-executive corporate and store employees in merit increases. Career advancement at CubeSmart is impossible unless the right political moves are made. Tuition assistance benefits are so limited that they are of little use when pursuing any kind of degree.

title: Challenging and rewarding company leading change in the self storage industry.

They are employee centric and are working to create a pipeline for talent identification, management training and a more defined path of advancement within the company for employees at all levels. They focus on customer service incorporating this into their corporate culture.
cons: While the company is growing there are not a lot of positions that open which limit advancement opportunities.

title: Manager
pros: The manager's job is relatively simple; accept payments, lease units, keep the property clean, and help with accounts receivable. That's the bulk of the job. Your volume of foot traffic can vary heavily depending upon the location of your property and the season (summer being the big rental season). This job was great for me while I was in junior college taking night classes, as my General Manager allowed me to keep my books under the desk and study/do homework whenever we had down-time (which during the winter was very often) and all of our daily tasks were finished.
cons: First, I would like to mention that I actually think this is a great job for younger people who are perhaps still in school and want to be able to put the title of Manager on a resume later in life. However, I will provide as much detail as possible on the Cons that I can easily think of just to provide you with as clear of a picture of the job's drawbacks as possible. Most of these were not significant enough to me personally to matter, but you should be aware of them so that you can judge for yourself how well you may fit in this position. I just don't want someone to see my long list of cons and think that it means the job is terrible or that I am trashing the company. I just like to be specific and thorough. Most properties have video cameras in the offices which are linked up to a DVR which your Area and District Managers can access freely. If you have a good DM and you are a good employee, then this is likely not going to be an issue for you. But, for those of you who may have a less than friendly DM, or who are generally uncomfortable with the possibility of being watched/recorded, then this may be an issue for you. Of course, customers can also be a source of stress, and any job in which you work with the public shares this hassle. Your experience in this position will vary heavily depending upon your General Manager (basically your immediate boss at your property, and likely the only other coworker you regularly see unless you cover other properties very often) and your District/Area Managers (which one of these two you interact with depends upon your district and company climate at the time. When I started, there was an area manager, then the position was eliminated and the area manager went back to being a normal GM, then a few years later another person was promoted to AM, and by the time I left there was talk of promoting a second AM). Managers have little control over how your accounts receivable and liens are handled, which are a big component of how your bonus is calculated. This means that if your GM decides to give a tenant an extra month to pay their past-due rent, or makes a mistake in their lien paperwork, or a variety of other situations, then you will lose a large portion of your bonus for that month(possibly quarter, I forget how often the bonuses were paid out) because your accounts receivable are too high. For that matter, the AR goals of all properties are calculated as a percentage of the property's total income, which is perfectly fine for most locations, but certain properties which are in worse neighborhoods will have consistently higher ARs and little hope of lowering them, and thus will not make much bonus money. Also, while your GM will be giving you an annual performance review, you do not get the opportunity to review your GM unless you deliberately complain to your AM or DM, which can cause you problems in a smaller office setting. Unfortunately, there is not a lot of room for advancement from this starting point in the company. It is rare that there is an opening for a new GM, and in such a case you should reach out to your DM and let them know if you are interested in the position (they typically will not think to ask Managers if they would be interested in the position unless the vacancy is at their home location). In a district that may have anywhere from 10 to 30 locations, there is normally only 1 or 2 area managers (and if I recall correctly, this position may require some college coursework or an associate's degree, but if interested, you should double check) and therefore even more rarely a chance to be promoted to this position. Promotion to DM is, in my experience, something like spotting a shooting star. You know that it happens, and you probably have friends who have seen it happen, but its not the sort of thing that's common. For one, being a DM requires a bachelors degree (at least it did when I worked there, so you many want to double check), and surprisingly few GMs or AMs have one of these. Also, it is more often the case that the properties in your district will simply be reassigned to another DM when a sudden vacancy in the position occurs (this happened when my DM sadly passed away). So, it would be hard for you to move into a DM position unless you knew that your current DM would be leaving, or that the company is looking to expand and create a new DM position, and you are willing to relocate for this purpose.

title: Bittersweet
pros: -Job is relatively easy to master -
cons: ecutive day off -Paid holidays, Sick time -Flexibility(depends on your GM) -Autonomy -Free uniforms

title: Culture, CS and Engagement focused
pros: Cubesmart is a great company to work with. They focus on CS and employee engagement. Loved the culture.
cons: Work load at times can be overwhelming but have learned this is typical of this type of position.

title: Great Opportunities, Great Training, Great Benefits!
pros: Training program is extensive, excellent for career advancement - the training that is available to its Teammates provides an great knowledge base. In addition the store levels have a great support system, from their Area Managers to District Managers and even up the line to the corporate offices. Great benefits are available including store bonuses.
cons: While there is a wonderful balance of work and personal time, some of the Holidays that the stores are kept open don't make sense.

title: Best Job I've Ever Had!
pros: A company that genuinely cares for its employees to the fullest extent. I am proud to be a part of this company. I am excited for my future within this company. I am always happy to meet every single new teammate I come across. I love spreading the same positive energy to new people that was shared with me.
cons: That we have to work on weekends.

title: So So
pros: Very easy work. If you have a 6th grade education, then you can do this. Very little actual physical activity.
cons: Micro managed to death. Responsibility without any real authority to actually do anything. The whole 'WOW' culture thing is a good idea, but it is completely outdated. It would have worked great back in the 1940's to 1960's. Not realistic in modern times. Entitled ass-holes that believe the world owes them something.

title: Review
pros: Most teammates were a pleasure to work with. The culture itself is amazing on paper.
cons: Many unqualified District Managers who play favoritism and their favorites are usually the ones who do not actually do their job. There's alot that can be exposed but I will say it is a decent job overall however if you have any real values and genuinely care about people this may not be the place for you. They do not practice what they preach but want you to. The pay is low for what we deal with everyday. Most of the employees are unhappy but stay because of the somewhat worklife balance.

title: High Expectations for low wages
pros: Health benefits decent vacation time wages are eh for store managers, wages are not so great for general managers (granted they do provide a on-site apartment for general managers provided its not in their plans to get rid of it)
cons: The company is focusing, developed by previous CEO Dean Jernigan, on giving the customer more than whats expected from a storage company. Corporate wants to provide the sites customers with a WOW experience to keep them coming back for more, if they need storage again in the future. Millions of dollars have been pumped into this program when, in my advice, this is not the way to go. You could argue the fact that they have won awards and this is because of the WOW program they have in place. I would say no though because when its time for awards to come around, they constantly spam store emails telling you to vote for the company and to tell friends to vote for them. If it was because of the WOW service everyone received, should we have to vote for ourselves every year, I think not. Someone on here said it best when they said "10-12 dollars is going to get you 10-12 dollars worth of service". The "you get what you pay for" applies here when it comes to people. Instead of pumping millions into creating a "culture" that everyone is supposed to follow and live out, pump those millions into recruiting and existing employees. Can we train our district managers to go out and look for talent instead of spoon feeding us a program that will only work if the person is willing to accept it? Find the right person in the first place and you don't have to worry about instilling VALUES and MISSION STATEMENTS and DEFINITION OF WOW! *according to CubeSmart* down everyones throats. Let's talk about rasies for a second, what a joke! If you have had an EXCEPTIONALLY well year, don't expect to get rewarded for it. The most people get is around 25 cents. If you get higher than that, your district manager has to take away from someone else to give to the other person. This is how it was explained to me by a former district manager. The company gives 2-3 percent, AT MOST 3 IF THEY HAD A GOOD YEAR, to give to the district manager to give to ALL employees in district. Talk about pathetic, take a look at the companies publicly traded symbol over the last few years, I'd say that the company has been doing pretty well yes? Year over year the company continues to grow and is trying to gain traction in the storage world. They do so because the people running the stores are doing something right but yet where is the reward? Maybe someone from corporate might rebuttal by saying they offer competitive wages, yea I don't think so, don't let them fool you.

title: New hire experience
pros: I have never in my 15 years of customer service experience ever felt so welcomed at a new job. The training has been very thorough and well explained . So many people available for you to reach out to for help and wonderfully maintained properties with exceptionally high standard
cons: The only con that I think i have really noticed is they could maybe make the military discounts also available to police firefighters and emt also . Other than that there isn't anything I would change

title: Good corporate culture
pros: Nice team-building workshops/district meetings, upper management was very attentive and actively engaged with the employees, there is a lot of room for growth within the company.
cons: The store manager position is equal parts administrative work/customer service/menial labor. You clean up after Customers a lot, including some very disgusting messes...

title: Used to be good
pros: -Free bagel fridays, -occasional fun team building events/baggo tournaments -Was able to briefly see a great company before the old CIO left and corporate culture turned toxic
cons: Upon the previous CIO leaving, management told us that we were a "good, not great" group encouraging us to do our best. I feel that they've only went downhill from "good": -Incompetent IT leadership, upper-level in particular comes off as clique-y and manipulative. Often pretends to be friendly with people and listen to concerns that end up ignored. If confronted on this, they will act like you just misunderstood the situation. this happened frequently. -People who have been there for years are slowly being pushed out and replaced with drones who can spout enough buzzwords to impress those who don't know any better, but with weak hard skills. A lot of good former employees would still be there today if corporate culture didn't change to support the toxic people. -Too much focus on hiring management positions rather than skilled workers. some of the skilled workers who are hired are not vetted well (due to hiring managers not having the technical skill to accurately assess a candidate's knowledge/performance) -Opportunities for advancement are few and far between (at least in IT), unless you apply for a management position. Even then, outside hires seem to be preferred first.

title: Interesting
pros: It's convenient, great teamwork, training. Set scheduling. The title is great to have if you went to school for business. This can build your leadership skills. Your day decides on how fast you move. If you know customer service and retail you'll be fine.
cons: Micro management, benefits, pay, opportunities for growth. If you plan on having a family it will be hard to balance. Maybe if your a DM this would be great to manage but if your just looking for a quick job you'll be okay

title: Keep looking
pros: paid every 2 weeks, onsite apartment, customers were usually half-decent people to deal with
cons: upper management, "bonus" system is a joke, being expected to go anywhere they want with no real notice

title: General Manager
pros: Steady work schedule for 40hrs a week. Out of work by 6pm the latest usually. Paid vacation and benefits are okay. Depending who is the District Manager the job may be okay for most people with the high standards it can be too much but it's manageable.
cons: A lot of gossip takes place in the workplace. It can be difficult to take vacation sometimes if coverage is not available for the store. If you have a District Manager that is all business and does not get to know you it can kill moral as they become judgemental by what others say about you. There can be a lot of knit picking when it comes to doing your job. For example, yes you may do a lot of things right but you didnt do this. The focus from the company feels like 25 percent focus of what you did right and 75 percent focus on what you did wrong. Company depends on mystery shops sometimes too much and although you may be freat at your job one slip up put you in that negative light of how you work. Pay is ok compared to other retail jobs but for a company to preach that they was everyone to have a career they need to increase wages. Word of advice if you want to raise a family, this job will not do. Career jobs pay around $20hr. You cant get to that point especially after they consolidated positions unless you work for corporate headquarters. Company try to bring in a positive culture to the company but ultimately feel it is a waste since the amount of work you do does not equal the same amount of money. Working outside on a hot day and putting up with attitudes to make you feel like an emotional punching bag does not equal the starting pay they offer you. There will be days you have to earn that $1 and it can suck but the worst is that you run the entire store with just 1 other person can stink. You work outside not matter what to clean an entire property which includes landscaping and then you have to deal with people that are pissed at you, pissed at the world, or mad because you had to close the office for 10 minutes to clean outside. It can be overwhelming depending on where your store is but for people who work hard this is just a stepping stone to have a title and move on 3yrs later for better opportunities.

title: Great Company
pros: The work life / home life balance is great. Corporate actually seems to care about the individuals. Great benefits. Currently, 100% maternity leave for 9 weeks!!!
cons: HR takes over a year to let people go that have no idea what they are doing. Taking vacation or sick days can be hard when there are only two employees at one location (you have to find coverage from other stores to be able get let your coworker have two days off during a work week) . The pay in the southeastern states are lacking at a livable pay.

title: Love the Culture
pros: Teammate/Family feel Great training with multiple resources and people to reach out to. Good health benefits. Employee Benefits. Vacation Time. On site living for some teammates.
cons: istent schedule and day time hours. Bonuses A very socially conscious and caring company. You can use several paid hours a year to volunteer and they offer a yearly donation match to specific charities.

title: Store Managers Be Careful
pros: Able to be inside and outside. Get to work alone some days.
cons: I can’t speak on all General Managers, but mine was so ignorant. They will boss the store manager around and relax in their office and pretend to be working on office stuff. The pay is NOT ENOUGH for the amount of work you will do outside in the heat. General Managers are put on a pedal stool while the store manager will take the fall for everything. Paid Bi-Weekly, run out of money between paychecks because they don’t pay enough.

title: Stay away
pros: Easy work environment & great hours. On average your teammates will be a great group that will all chip in to help out.
cons: Upper management is not helpful, but probably because they are overworked & underpaid like us in the trenches. Stop running the stores with a skeleton crew. Always having to leave the office unattended while we go show rooms, or do maintenance work in the building is bad. Customers hate it and yell at us non-stop because of this. But I guess corporate is trying to save as much $ as they can.

title: Great place to work!
pros: I am new to CubeSmart. The industry where I came from was very different than this environment, but I have to say it is a breath of fresh air for me. Since day one, I have had a very positive experience. My team is very hard working and really care about their positions. I can see from previous and current opportunities that there are several internal promotions and room for growth and opportunity. The benefits package is very competitive and the values and mission show through from everyone. I am lucky to be here!
cons: I do not see any Cons.

title: Ok for a short time, but don't get stuck here
pros: Enjoyable part of the job are the coworkers. I love my fellow store employees. We go above and beyond to help each other.
cons: Management leaves a lot to be desired. District Managers often push off their responsibilities to General Managers and Senior GMs, especially when it comes to teammate discipline which is something only DMs are supposed to do. District Managers very rarely follow through on anything, and firing terrible employees just doesn't happen - they would prefer you just quit. CEO is full of it. Every year the store employee bonus program is restructured and our bonus pools get smaller. Pay is terrible for the work performed. Upward movement is non-existent anymore. Lots of hiring from Public Storage now, which is known for low-quality candidates, and the work culture is adjusting accordingly. Managers and District Managers who come from Public Storage often "don't get it" and try to do things the PS way - which is counter to CubeSmart's mission and values. Often times when DMs come from PS they bring in their own PS people and create a clique - if you aren't from PS you don't get recognition and are overlooked for opportunities in these districts. WOW! culture seems to only apply at the store level and from store employees to customers. Corporate employees and district managers do not engage in culture when dealing with store employees. You are talked down to a lot by fellow employees at corporate. This started occurring after Chris Marr took over, which shows it is likely an issue stemming from the top. Hardest part of the job is dealing with upset customers. People get upset for the strangest reasons and they often are not justified. It takes a lot of energy to deal with, but over time you grow accustomed and know how to deliver that WOW service.

title: HQ - A mixed opportunity.
pros: Beautiful HQ with a comfortable environment, plenty of work space, in-house gym, spaces in which to socialize and have informal conversations with co-workers aka teammates and plenty of office related activities to build team-work. The provided fruit and gas grills available all four seasons were nice amenities. The CEO and management team were accessible for professional networking or to simply chat should the opportunity present itself -- that's invaluable and a true benefit to working in the company and HQ. Most teammates were approachable and friendly. In general, there was a will to solve problems and collaborate as needed and time allowed.
cons: The organization's rate of growth over the past few years severely stressed existing personnel. While the growth should be applauded, it came at a significant cost to human resources. Some departments hired more staff to handle their respective workloads while others did not. The disparity in staffing levels and workloads impacted managers and staff alike with uneven opportunities for [formal and informal] professional development, nearly unavailable middle management who seemed to be buried in one project or another, varying levels of individual burnout and curtailed networking opportunities being examples. It was truly hellacious. Project management skill sets across the organization were not readily apparent. The lack of applied standard PM practices critically harmed company initiatives with long-term impact on both HQ and retail teammates. In some cases, the project resources assigned to task execution were stretched beyond any reasonable expectation given existing workloads and rates of compensation. This made for some jaw dropping scenarios. For job candidates, it will be important to understand the workload (easily quantifiable in the context of CubeSmart), available staffing and potential professional opportunities prior to accepting a position. Asking the hard questions up front and making sure that the financial ask is inline with the presented work conditions will set up the candidate for a decent experience in the organization. It is possible to find a really good work group in the company. Benefits were OK, but not amazing. Due diligence with compensation and benefits offered v. workload and defined professional opportunities for growth is a must!

title: Cubesmart is not "Heart Full", but heartless
pros: Steady work, friendly co-workers, and some great district managers.
cons: The "royalty/peasant" mentality with the upper echelon of Cubesmart, being anyone above the district managers. My Divisional Vice President and his administrative assistant looked down their noses at the facility employees, treating them like chattle. Three examples: 1) When Cubesmart was planning to purchase my old site, the DVP and his adminstrative assistant came to visit the site. The Admin Asst asked me what I usually do for lunch. I told her that on my way from the bank deposit, I stop at the Burger at the corner of our street and pick up my lunch on the way back. In a haughty voice she said, "Well, we're going to put a stop to THAT!" meaning that I shouldn't get my lunch on business time. 2) When I was asked by the DVP what my hourly rate was, he said "OK, good" and left it to my very personable District Manager to tell me that since I was making more than any other manager in the area, that my salary would be cut by 75 cents an hour, in case any other managers were to find out what I was making. I told him that I earned that money over the years, and he shrugged his shoulders and said sorry. 3) Working on Sundays was mandatory for Assistant Manager, and instead of making the business hours employee friendly ( like 9 am to 1 pm) the store hours are 11-3, pretty much ruining any effort to have some family time on Sunday.

title: Requiring face masks
pros: Reasonable hours; Pay raises are only 2%
cons: They sent out a survey to all employees, as they do every year asking what the employees satisfaction is. Once the survey has ended they send a memo requiring ALL employees to wear a face mask starting late May. Disgusting and appalling! It is my body and its an abuse of power to tell me I need to cover my face which has been proven to do nothing against the virus, or else I cant feed my family. They also open a 401k in your name using your identity WITHOUT permission and begin taking money out of your check automatically. Once you tell them to stop they wont remove money but they wont close the 401k in your name either.

title: Can be great for some, terrible for others
pros: CubeSmart is a great place to work for if you enjoy working independently, being in a laid back environment, sales and marketing, and are at a point in your life where you're not really looking to move up but are just looking for stability. As a GM you manage a facility with typically only one other employee. Many times you and the manager will not work at the same time as it is not often busy enough for the need of two employees. If you enjoy working alone this can be great, if not then this might not be the position for you.
cons: Many times the maintenance responsibilities are performed by the GM and Manager which can be a bit strenuous at times. Regular cleaning and maintenance includes sweeping, dusting, mopping, landscaping, cutting the grass, leaf blowing, and in some cases even cleaning the gutters on the storage units. Facilities with one large building that houses indoor units are typically easier to maintain than facilities with several buildings and indoor and outdoor storage. The primary drawback to this position is that there are not many opportunities to move up. It's not hard to move from manager to GM if the position comes available but being a general manager is about as high up as many will get. While they have Area Managers and District Managers the positions do not come available very often and they take into accountability years with the company. At the time I lived on site which was a nice bonus but the two bedroom apartments are very small at times and you have zero privacy. It's not uncommon to have customers come to your door in the middle of the night because they lost their key, forgot their gate code, or need to make a payment.

title: If you are a student do NOT work for this company
pros: Honestly there weren't too many pros of working for this company. I really don't even think I have a whole lot to say about the good things.
cons: Management favoritism- My first actual week at my store, the man that hired me (DM) was fired. So then another DM was going to be in charge of our store. I met the man in person once. I had one GM when I started who I LOVED and she got pushed out to bring another GM in. The GM that was hired to take her place had not worked for this company before and was hired in as GM even though there were plenty of store managers in the area who were way more qualified for the position. This GM had the DM wrapped around her little finger. Anything she wanted she got. Not a flexible schedule- Going into this job I did not know that I would be starting school again. So when I found out what my school schedule was going to be I notified my DM right away. It took a couple days to hear back from him but even then I didn't hear back. He called my GM to have her tell me that it would not be possible for them to work with me on my schedule. All I was asking was to leave 30 minutes early everyday so that I could make it to class on time. He didn't even have the nerve to tell me himself. He had someone else do it. That seemed to be the case on many occasions. Calling in sick- If you are sick, just go to work anyway. Calling in was the biggest hassle. You have to call your DM, then your AM, then your GM. I had strep throat and was told to stay in bed. But I tried calling in and my DM made it sound like it was the biggest hassle in the world. Even though my GM was also scheduled that day. Most days you really only need one person in the office. So he basically guilted me into coming into work where I sat all day and did nothing because I was so sick.

title: Disappointed in the CEO and at the direction CubeSmart is going employee wise...
pros: A pro is the 401K match, however, most field employees don't make enough to take full advantage of it. Plus it's through TransAmerica, hefty "maintenance" fees are paid yearly. Example, I was able to put $300 for the year and the company matched with $200, I paid a "maintenance fee" if $135..... yeah, so saving for the little guy is hard to do. So I guess ultimately even the 401K is a Con....?
cons: I Will preface this with CubeSmart has a HUGE employee turnover rate - people quitting, not getting fired. It's extremely hard to get fired. A lot of people from the Corporate office have left in the past few years too. So keep that in mind as you read this. Also know that CubeSMart is GOOD for a college student, a person who just needs just any job for the time being, it's also good for people who are getting close to retirement age and need to earn less to collect full social security. 1.) Cuts - Constantly looking for ways to take from the field employees. Most recent example, getting rid of the Area Manager position. ****UPDATE 12/23/15 - since you will be change from salary to hourly pay that will cause the checks to be short a weeks pay. Instead of getting paid for 2 weeks you will get paid for one since you will not be paid in real time anymore. So to help the employees out that will be getting a short check CubeSmart is allowing you to...... ready for this...? To apply any unused vacation time to make up for the short check. So, you can lose your vacation time to make up for a change the company made that caused your check to be short. Talk about WOWing! the employees. Now, we will get a new title of "Senior Manager" or whatever they call it and we will still have same responsibilities and doing the same work, but no more mileage and no more visiting other stores. Why is this important? Because when getting promoted to Area Manger they negotiate LOW PAY and say how "since you will be getting mileage the pay will be lower". So, some genius up in Corporate found another way to cut from the people who can least afford it instead of cutting the fat up in the Corporate office. 2.) Bonuses - So, every year the field employees get a $100 bonus. However, that $100 becomes roughly $75 after taxes lol. Also be careful with the "WOW cards", they tax those too. Before the current CEO got in we actually had a nice incentive bonus structure. We'd get a bonus for beating revenue, selling of merchandise, total square footage and accrued rent. My store would get $600 - $700/month in bonuses for hitting all our goals. Enter new generation CEO, now we are lucky to see $40/month... Again, kudos to Corporate for looking out for their employees. 3.) Moral - Here's a good way to know moral is at an all time high at the company, when field employees are asked to write 5 star reviews on GlassDoor. Back story on this is, we were at a district meeting and they started talking about company reviews. Well that eventually lead to employees reviewing the company on GlassDoor. As you can see the reviews aren't too favorable and I see exactly why they went to the lowest on the totem pole to write 5 star reviews. 4.) Pay - Again, CubeSmart is ALWAYS looking for ways to cut your pay. You transfer to a different state, no matter what state - pay cut. You live on site - pay cut. Your promotion and year review hit around the same time - you get screwed. "Well we just gave you a raise for your promotion so your yearly raise is included in that". 5.) Advancement - So lately CubeSmart started releasing weekly video called "Teammate Spotlight". The theme seems to be "so and so is a PERFECT EXAMPLE of how you can advance in the company.". Sure people in corporate can advance at a faster pace than the field employees. In the field you RARELY get to advance unless you are in the right place at the right time OR a favorite. When you have a few GM's that have been in the position for 7, 10, 15 years... you know you can't advance too easy. Also, it's really easy to get stuck behind a GM that is clueless but CubeSmart will keep them in the position as long as the store is running without complaints from Customers. 6.) General Cons - Customer Service - While they have set hours the store is open, be expecting to work off the clock when you get that call from the call center about a Customer on property trying to move in after hours, or needs their lock cut because they lost their key. Think you can get a little overtime for your time spent WOWing the Customer? Think again, the company expects you to do it with a smile and if you punch in, they expect you to cut it later by taking a longer lunch or leaving early. If you DON'T punch in and gladly do it, they company thinks you are the greatest thing since sliced bread. Over Time - The company has a strict policy about no over time. Get that last minute Customer that comes in at 5:58PM to move in? Don' think staying late to give that outstanding Customer service will get you a little bonus over time. You are again, expected to cut it. The call center calls you at 9PM because a Customer was running late and just has to move in tonight? Go help them, WOW the Customer and then make sure you cut the over time. See the pattern here....? WOW the Customer but screw the employee. Favoritism - Seems like a lot of District Managers like yes men/women, If you are one of those or simply a brown noser, you WILL get special treatment. 7.) Health Care - Another joke. High premiums and complicated plans. I will leave it at that.

title: Understand what you are getting into before you accept their offer.
pros: -Possible time to study depending on the store. -Somewhat flexible scheduling. -Simple work that requires little thought, other than trained repetition of certain systems and tasks. -Free bottled water. -Networking with customers
cons: If you are a young person (20 - 30) it can be an ideal job while you are attending school. This is because at slower stores you'll likely be able to study on the job between taking care of administrative tasks and general maintenance. I would suggest visiting the store you may be working to gauge how busy it is. If it is a busy store, or in a bad area, then then you'll likely have no time to study. The reason I mention studying for younger employees is because this company caters to people who lack ambition, or are retired, and have no other ambition except to stay busy for 12 to 15 dollars an hour (maybe a little more depending on the area, but it may be less in other areas). CubeSmart is a somewhat ideal job while someone is making a transition in life, but given that there is few opportunities for advancement in position or pay I would label it a dead-end job. Yes, in some instances an employee may be offered residence on site (if an apartment exists), but it is not free of charge as some might believe. If an employee leases an apartment on site then more than likely that employee will be the emergency contact, and be required to take care of all the problems that occur after hours. In my experience all kinds of crazy, shady things, occur at night at storage facilities. Just ask anyone who has worked in the industry. Understand that if you are in a store manager position you will be required to clean the entire facility, spray for weeds, general maintenance, handle auctions, retail operations, collection calls, ect., often times by yourself. Be aware that you will be receiving commission for rentals, and the current bonus system may only yield you 100 dollars a month or less. If you need a job to get through a rough patch, then this company will work. My recommendation is to act like you're drinking the "Kool-Aid" but please do not swallow it. Otherwise you might find yourself there 10 years later, getting 25 cent raises each year (maybe), and nothing to really show for your time. If you decide to work at CubeSmart then take my advice and learn a skill set while you are there so you can move on to something better.
